fr.sii.ogham.email.builder.javamail

Class JavaMailBuilder

  • java.lang.Object
    • fr.sii.ogham.core.builder.AbstractParent<EmailBuilder>
      • fr.sii.ogham.email.builder.javamail.JavaMailBuilder
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    ActivableAtRuntime, Builder<JavaMailSender>, Parent<EmailBuilder>

    public class JavaMailBuilder
extends AbstractParent<EmailBuilder>
implements Builder<JavaMailSender>, ActivableAtRuntime
    Configures how Java Mail implementation will send Emails.

    To send Email using Java Mail, you need to register this builder into a MessagingBuilder like this: 

     
 MessagingBuilder msgBuilder = ...
 msgBuilder.email()
    .sender(JavaMailBuilder.class)    // registers the builder and accesses to that builder for configuring it
    Once the builder is registered, sending email through Java Mail requires at least host of the SMTP server. You can define it using: 
     
 msgBuilder.email()
    .sender(JavaMailBuilder.class)    // registers the builder and accesses to that builder for configuring it
       .host("localhost")
    Or you can also use property keys (using interpolation): 
     
 msgBuilder
 .environment()
    .properties()
       .set("custom.property.for.host", "localhost")
       .and()
    .and()
 .email()
    .sender(JavaMailBuilder.class)    // registers the builder and accesses to that builder for configuring it
       .host("${custom.property.for.host}")
    You can do the same with port of the SMTP server.

    SMTP server may require authentication. In most cases, authentication is done using username/password. You can use this builder to quickly provide your username and password: 

     
 .sender(JavaMailBuilder.class)
    .authenticator()
        .username("foo")
        .password("bar")
    If you need another authentication mechanism, you can directly provide your own Authenticator implementation: 
     
 .sender(JavaMailBuilder.class)
    .authenticator(new MyCustomAuthenticator())

    Finally, Ogham will transform general Email object into MimeMessage, MimeMultipart, MimeBodyPart objects. This transformation will fit almost all use cases but you may need to customize a part of the javax.mail message. Instead of doing again the same work Ogham does, this builder allows you to intercept the message to modify it just before sending it: 

     
 .sender(JavaMailBuilder.class)
    .intercept(new MyCustomInterceptor())
    See JavaMailInterceptor for more information.
    Author:
    Aur√©lien Baudet

    • Method Detail

      • host

        public JavaMailBuilder host(String... host)
        Set the mail server address host (IP or hostname). You can specify a direct value. For example: 
         .host("localhost");

        You can also specify one or several property keys. For example: 

         .host("${custom.property.high-priority}", "${custom.property.low-priority}");
        The properties are not immediately evaluated. The evaluation will be done when the build() method is called. If you provide several property keys, evaluation will be done on the first key and if the property exists (see EnvironmentBuilder), its value is used. If the first property doesn't exist in properties, then it tries with the second one and so on.
        Parameters:
        host - one value, or one or several property keys
        Returns:
        this instance for fluent chaining

      • port

        public JavaMailBuilder port(int port)
        Set the mail server port. This value preempts any other value defined by calling port(String...) method. If this method is called several times, only the last value is used.
        Parameters:
        port - the port to use
        Returns:
        this instance for fluent chaining

      • port

        public JavaMailBuilder port(Integer port)
        Set the mail server port. This version allows null value. In this case, the null value is skipped. This value preempts any other value defined by calling port(String...) method. If this method is called several times, only the last value is used.
        Parameters:
        port - the port to use (may be null)
        Returns:
        this instance for fluent chaining

      • port

        public JavaMailBuilder port(String... port)
        Set the mail server port. You can specify a direct value. For example: 
         .port("25");

        You can also specify one or several property keys. For example: 

         .port("${custom.property.high-priority}", "${custom.property.low-priority}");
        The properties are not immediately evaluated. The evaluation will be done when the build() method is called. If you provide several property keys, evaluation will be done on the first key and if the property exists (see EnvironmentBuilder), its value is used. If the first property doesn't exist in properties, then it tries with the second one and so on.
        Parameters:
        port - one value, or one or several property keys
        Returns:
        this instance for fluent chaining

      • charset

        public JavaMailBuilder charset(String... charsets)
        Set charset to use for email body. You can specify a direct value. For example: 
         .charset("UTF-8");

        You can also specify one or several property keys. For example: 

         .charset("${custom.property.high-priority}", "${custom.property.low-priority}");
        The properties are not immediately evaluated. The evaluation will be done when the build() method is called. If you provide several property keys, evaluation will be done on the first key and if the property exists (see EnvironmentBuilder), its value is used. If the first property doesn't exist in properties, then it tries with the second one and so on.
        Parameters:
        charsets - one value, or one or several property keys
        Returns:
        this instance for fluent chaining

      • charset

        public JavaMailBuilder charset(Charset charset)
        Set charset to use for email body. This value preempts any other value defined by calling charset(String...) method. If this method is called several times, only the last value is used.
        Parameters:

        Returns:
        this instance for fluent chaining

      • charset

        public JavaMailBuilder charset(CharsetDetector charsetDetector)
        Defines a custom detector that will indicate which charset corresponds for a particular string. This value preempts any other value defined by calling charset(Charset) method. If this method is called several times, only the last provider is used.
        Parameters:
        charsetDetector - the provider used to detect charset of a string
        Returns:
        this instance for fluent chaining

      • authenticator

        public JavaMailBuilder authenticator(javax.mail.Authenticator authenticator)

         .sender(JavaMailBuilder.class)

      • environment

        public EnvironmentBuilder<JavaMailBuilder> environment()
        Configures environment for the builder (and sub-builders). Environment consists of configuration properties/values that are used to configure the system (see EnvironmentBuilder for more information). You can use system properties: 
         .environment()
    .systemProperties();
        Or, you can load properties from a file: 
         .environment()
    .properties("/path/to/file.properties")
        Or using directly a Properties object: 
         Properties myprops = new Properties();
 myprops.setProperty("foo", "bar");
 .environment()
    .properties(myprops)
        Or defining directly properties: 
         .environment()
    .properties()
       .set("foo", "bar")

        If no environment was previously used, it creates a new one. Then each time you call environment(), the same instance is used.

        Returns:
        the builder to configure properties handling

      • environment

        public JavaMailBuilder environment(EnvironmentBuilder<?> builder)
        NOTE: this is mostly for advance usage (when creating a custom module). Inherits environment configuration from another builder. This is useful for configuring independently different parts of Ogham but keeping a whole coherence (see DefaultJavaMailConfigurer for an example of use). The same instance is shared meaning that all changes done here will also impact the other builder.

        If a previous builder was defined (by calling environment() for example), the new builder will override it.

        Parameters:
        builder - the builder to inherit
        Returns:
        this instance for fluent chaining

      • intercept

        public JavaMailBuilder intercept(JavaMailInterceptor interceptor)
        Ogham will transform general Email object into MimeMessage, MimeMultipart, MimeBodyPart objects. This transformation will fit almost all use cases but you may need to customize a part of the javax.mail message. Instead of doing again the same work Ogham does, this builder allows you to intercept the message to modify it just before sending it: 
         .sender(JavaMailBuilder.class)
    .intercept(new MyCustomInterceptor())
        See JavaMailInterceptor for more information.
        Parameters:
        interceptor - the custom interceptor used to modify MimeMessage
        Returns:
        this instance for fluent chaining

      • mimetype

        public MimetypeDetectionBuilder<JavaMailBuilder> mimetype()
        Builder that configures mimetype detection. Detection is used here to detect mimetype of Attachments. There exists several implementations to provide the mimetype:
        • Using Java MimetypesFileTypeMap
        • Using Java 7 Files.probeContentType(java.nio.file.Path)
        • Using Apache Tika
        • Using JMimeMagic

        Both implementations provided by Java are based on file extensions. This can't be used in most cases as we often handle InputStreams.

        In previous version of Ogham, JMimeMagic was used and was working quite well. Unfortunately, the library is no more maintained.

        You can configure how Tika will detect mimetype: 

         .mimetype()
    .tika()
       ...

        This builder allows to use several providers. It will chain them until one can find a valid mimetype. If none is found, you can explicitly provide the default one: 

         .mimetype()
    .defaultMimetype("text/html")

        If no mimetype detector was previously defined, it creates a new one. Then each time you call mimetype(), the same instance is used.

        Returns:
        the builder to configure mimetype detection

      • mimetype

        public JavaMailBuilder mimetype(MimetypeDetectionBuilder<?> builder)
        NOTE: this is mostly for advance usage (when creating a custom module). Inherits mimetype configuration from another builder. This is useful for configuring independently different parts of Ogham but keeping a whole coherence. The same instance is shared meaning that all changes done here will also impact the other builder.

        If a previous builder was defined (by calling mimetype() for example), the new builder will override it.

        Parameters:
        builder - the builder to inherit
        Returns:
        this instance for fluent chaining
